content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines a State as a State of the United States, the District of Columbia, and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. The Attorney General can designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for Federal assistance based on specific criteria. The Attorney General can provide Federal assistance to high-intensity interstate gang activity areas by establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders in those areas. Reassignment or detailing of personnel from any Federal department or agency may be directed for this purpose. The Attorney General can provide Federal assistance by establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. This includes reassigning personnel from Federal departments or agencies and providing necessary funding for the operation of these teams. The Attorney General can establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, providing necessary funding for their operation and facilitating national and regional meetings for intelligence sharing and best practices. Each team's composition is specified. The Attorney General can establish criminal street gang enforcement teams in high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, providing necessary funding for their operation. Each team shall consist of agents and officers from various federal agencies. The Attorney General can designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, considering levels of gang crime activity and involving various federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General considers current and predicted levels of gang crime activity, the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, and the resources committed by state and local law enforcement agencies to address the gang crime problem. The Attorney General evaluates the resources allocated by law enforcement agencies to respond to gang crime, including participation in a criminal street gang enforcement team, the potential impact of increased federal resources on local response to gang crime, and any other relevant criteria deemed appropriate. Additionally, the Attorney General may appoint additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys. The Attorney General may appoint up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. Appropriations are authorized as needed for this purpose. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims. Grants to hire additional prosecutors, fund technology, equipment, and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders. The text chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations for grants to hire prosecutors, fund technology, equipment, and training to accurately identify and prosecute gang members and violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations for grants to establish state-wide crime prevention databases is provided under SEC. 320936, with $20,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012. SEC. 320936 authorizes grants for State and local law enforcement to establish State-wide crime prevention databases, with funding allocated as needed.
